title: Galaxy Z Fold 7 vs Fold 6: Upgrades in Display, Power and Design
description: Samsung has unveiled the Galaxy Z Fold 7. This premium foldable phone brings significant hardware upgrades and design…
author: Peter Holden
excerpt: Samsung has unveiled the Galaxy Z Fold 7. This premium foldable phone brings significant hardware upgrades and design refinements compared to last year's
text: Samsung has unveiled the Galaxy Z Fold 7. This premium foldable phone brings significant hardware upgrades and design refinements compared to last year's Galaxy Z Fold 6. The excitement is building among foldable enthusiasts who want to know exactly what's new, what's improved, and whether the upgrade justifies the investment. Bigger, Brighter, Lighter: Display and Design Upgrades The Galaxy Z Fold 7 showcases impressive visual improvements that immediately catch the eye. The main screen expands to 8.0 inches from the Fold 6's 7.6 inches, while the cover screen grows to 6.5 inches from 6.3 inches. Both displays feature Dynamic AMOLED 2X technology. The Fold 7's screens are brighter and more vibrant. This creates an even more immersive experience for video streaming, gaming, or multitasking workflows that demand visual clarity and rich color reproduction. Samsung has also refined the physical design significantly. The Fold 7 is sleeker when both closed and open, and it's a full 24 grams lighter than its predecessor. Material upgrades include a stronger Advanced Armor Aluminum frame and Gorilla Glass Ceramic 2 protection, which boost durability while maintaining the premium feel that users expect from Samsung's flagship foldable lineup. Samsung Power Up: Performance, Battery, and Connectivity Under the hood lies the custom Snapdragon 8 Elite chip. This processor delivers faster speeds and better multitasking performance compared to the Fold 6's already powerful Snapdragon 8 Gen 3. RAM gets upgraded to 16GB on the top-tier model. Wi-Fi 7 brings cutting-edge wireless performance that future-proofs connectivity for years to come. These improvements matter for power users who push their devices to the limits with demanding applications and extensive multitasking. Both devices feature the same 4400mAh dual battery configuration. Fast wired and wireless charging remain unchanged, as does Wireless PowerShare functionality. While battery life won't see dramatic improvements, the overall performance and connectivity enhancements provide meaningful benefits for intensive users. Samsung Next-Level Cameras and Imaging Features The camera system receives the most dramatic upgrade. The Fold 7 features a new 200MP main camera, representing a massive leap from the Fold 6's 50MP sensor. This change promises jaw-dropping detail and clarity for capturing both everyday moments and special occasions. The secondary cameras also see refinements to the ultra-wide and telephoto options, maintaining the 3X optical zoom capability while improving low-light performance across the board. Samsung made an interesting change to the selfie setup by replacing the under-display camera with a punch-hole 10MP shooter. This modification results in sharper front-facing shots, making the Fold 7 a more serious contender for smartphone photographers who demand quality from every lens. Samsung Software, OS Enhancements, and Futureproofing Out of the box, the Z Fold 7 runs Android 16 with One UI 8. The Fold 6 shipped with Android 14 and One UI 6.1.1. This gives the newer device a significant head start in terms of software features and security. The Fold 7 benefits from Samsung's extended update roadmap. Expect more years of security patches and major OS upgrades. Improved foldable multitasking features streamline the user experience. Intuitive app pairing and enhanced S Pen functionality are included, making the foldable form factor more productive and enjoyable. These software improvements, combined with the upgraded hardware, position the Fold 7 as a more future-ready investment. Price, Water Resistance, and Should You Upgrade? Pricing for the Z Fold 7 starts at $1999 for the base 256GB model. This represents a $100 increase over the Fold 6's launch price. Both devices maintain an IP48 rating for dust and water resistance, so no improvements here. For current Z Fold 6 owners, the upgrade appeal depends on specific priorities. Those who crave bleeding-edge camera capabilities, a sleeker design, and faster performance will find the most value in upgrading. If you're coming from an older foldable model or want the latest Android experience with better futureproofing, the Z Fold 7's comprehensive suite of upgrades makes it a compelling investment for serious foldable enthusiasts. Samsung's Galaxy Z Fold 7 clearly raises the bar for premium foldables. The brighter displays, upgraded camera system, lighter build, and improved performance create a package that delivers genuine value for power users and enthusiasts. While the price has increased slightly, the IP48 rating remains unchanged. If futureproofing, camera quality, and refined design matter to you, the Fold 7 leads the foldable market into its next evolution. html:
Samsung has unveiled the Galaxy Z Fold 7. This premium foldable phone brings significant hardware upgrades and design refinements compared to last year's Galaxy Z Fold 6. The excitement is building among foldable enthusiasts who want to know exactly what's new, what's improved, and whether the upgrade justifies the investment.

Bigger, Brighter, Lighter: Display and Design Upgrades

The Galaxy Z Fold 7 showcases impressive visual improvements that immediately catch the eye. The main screen expands to 8.0 inches from the Fold 6's 7.6 inches, while the cover screen grows to 6.5 inches from 6.3 inches.

Both displays feature Dynamic AMOLED 2X technology. The Fold 7's screens are brighter and more vibrant. This creates an even more immersive experience for video streaming, gaming, or multitasking workflows that demand visual clarity and rich color reproduction.

Samsung has also refined the physical design significantly. The Fold 7 is sleeker when both closed and open, and it's a full 24 grams lighter than its predecessor. Material upgrades include a stronger Advanced Armor Aluminum frame and Gorilla Glass Ceramic 2 protection, which boost durability while maintaining the premium feel that users expect from Samsung's flagship foldable lineup.

Power Up: Performance, Battery, and Connectivity

Under the hood lies the custom Snapdragon 8 Elite chip. This processor delivers faster speeds and better multitasking performance compared to the Fold 6's already powerful Snapdragon 8 Gen 3.

RAM gets upgraded to 16GB on the top-tier model. Wi-Fi 7 brings cutting-edge wireless performance that future-proofs connectivity for years to come. These improvements matter for power users who push their devices to the limits with demanding applications and extensive multitasking.

Both devices feature the same 4400mAh dual battery configuration. Fast wired and wireless charging remain unchanged, as does Wireless PowerShare functionality. While battery life won't see dramatic improvements, the overall performance and connectivity enhancements provide meaningful benefits for intensive users.

Next-Level Cameras and Imaging Features

The camera system receives the most dramatic upgrade. The Fold 7 features a new 200MP main camera, representing a massive leap from the Fold 6's 50MP sensor.

This change promises jaw-dropping detail and clarity for capturing both everyday moments and special occasions. The secondary cameras also see refinements to the ultra-wide and telephoto options, maintaining the 3X optical zoom capability while improving low-light performance across the board.

Samsung made an interesting change to the selfie setup by replacing the under-display camera with a punch-hole 10MP shooter. This modification results in sharper front-facing shots, making the Fold 7 a more serious contender for smartphone photographers who demand quality from every lens.

Software, OS Enhancements, and Futureproofing

Out of the box, the Z Fold 7 runs Android 16 with One UI 8. The Fold 6 shipped with Android 14 and One UI 6.1.1. This gives the newer device a significant head start in terms of software features and security.

The Fold 7 benefits from Samsung's extended update roadmap. Expect more years of security patches and major OS upgrades.

Improved foldable multitasking features streamline the user experience. Intuitive app pairing and enhanced S Pen functionality are included, making the foldable form factor more productive and enjoyable. These software improvements, combined with the upgraded hardware, position the Fold 7 as a more future-ready investment.

Price, Water Resistance, and Should You Upgrade?

Pricing for the Z Fold 7 starts at $1999 for the base 256GB model. This represents a $100 increase over the Fold 6's launch price. Both devices maintain an IP48 rating for dust and water resistance, so no improvements here.

For current Z Fold 6 owners, the upgrade appeal depends on specific priorities. Those who crave bleeding-edge camera capabilities, a sleeker design, and faster performance will find the most value in upgrading.

If you're coming from an older foldable model or want the latest Android experience with better futureproofing, the Z Fold 7's comprehensive suite of upgrades makes it a compelling investment for serious foldable enthusiasts.

Samsung's Galaxy Z Fold 7 clearly raises the bar for premium foldables. The brighter displays, upgraded camera system, lighter build, and improved performance create a package that delivers genuine value for power users and enthusiasts. While the price has increased slightly, the IP48 rating remains unchanged. If futureproofing, camera quality, and refined design matter to you, the Fold 7 leads the foldable market into its next evolution.

By the numbers: 

With over a decade's experience covering the world of Android and having reviewed more devices than he can count, Peter is excited about where the world of tech is heading. He is currently packing the Oppo Find X8 Pro, OnePlus Pad 2, and an ASUS Chromebook Plus.
